How to Cite Business Strategy and the Environment in APA Format

Complete guide to citing Business Strategy and the Environment in APA 7th edition with examples, unique formatting requirements, and common issues specific to this source.

Business Strategy and the Environment presents unique citation challenges that require specific guidance beyond general source type rules. This page provides targeted help for finding citation information, handling Business Strategy and the Environment's particular format requirements, and avoiding common mistakes specific to this platform.

Quick Reference: Business Strategy and the Environment Citations

Reference List Format:
Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx

Business Strategy and the Environment-Specific Notes:
Citing articles from "Business Strategy and the Environment" (BSE) in APA 7th edition follows the general guidelines for journal articles, but there are some nuances that students should be aware of. In APA format, you list up to 20 authors for a single work. For BSE, this rule applies, and you should ensure all authors are included in the citation for any article with 20 or fewer authors. The format would be: Author(s) Last name, Initials. (Year). Title of the article. Business Strategy and the Environment, Volume(Issue), page range. https://doi.org/xxxx. Pay special attention to the DOI, as it is a persistent identifier that provides a direct link to the article, and BSE articles typically include them.

A common point of confusion arises with the treatment of the article title and journal name. In APA format, the article title is written in sentence case, meaning only the first word of the title, the first word after a colon, and proper nouns are capitalized. However, students often mistakenly capitalize all significant words, which is incorrect. The journal name, however, is capitalized and italicized. Best practices for citing BSE articles include double-checking author order and ensuring DOI accuracy. Additionally, students should verify they have not mistakenly italicized the article title, which is a frequent error. Keeping these details in mind will help students avoid common pitfalls and ensure their citations are precise and in line with APA standards.

In-Text Citation:
- Parenthetical: ([Author], [Year])
- Narrative: [Author] ([Year])

Where to Find Citation Information on Business Strategy and the Environment

To effectively locate citation information for articles from "Business Strategy and the Environment," follow this detailed guide. This journal is accessible through the Wiley Online Library, and understanding its layout will help you efficiently gather the necessary details for citation purposes.

  1. Author Information:
    - Upon accessing an article from "Business Strategy and the Environment," the author byline is typically located directly underneath the article's title at the top of the page. You may see multiple authors listed, and their names are often linked to their respective profiles, which can provide additional information such as their institutional affiliations.

  2. Publication Date:
    - The publication date is usually displayed just below the authors' names. It typically includes the day, month, and year of publication. If only the issue date is available, it might appear in the citation section or the article's abstract page on Wiley's site.

  3. Article Title:
    - The title of the article is prominently displayed at the top of the page. It is usually in a larger, bold font to distinguish it from other text on the page. Ensure that you note the full title as it appears, including any subtitles, for accurate citation.

  4. URL/Access Information:
    - The URL for the article is found in the browser's address bar at the top of the web page. This is the direct link to the article and should be copied exactly as it appears. If accessing through an institution, verify if the link includes any proxy information, as this should be omitted in citations.

  5. DOI (Digital Object Identifier):
    - While not initially requested, the DOI is a crucial part of citing journal articles. It is usually located in the article's header or footer and is prefixed with "https://doi.org/". Including the DOI in your citation ensures that the article can be reliably located.

  6. Unique Navigation Tips:
    - The Wiley Online Library often features a sidebar or menu with options such as "Abstract," "Full Text," and "References." Use these to navigate directly to the sections of the article that might contain additional citation details.
    - For comprehensive citation information, you can also use the "Cite" tool available on the article page. This tool may provide formatted citation details in various styles, including APA.

By following these steps, students can efficiently gather all necessary citation information from "Business Strategy and the Environment," ensuring their academic work is accurately referenced.

Step-by-Step: Creating Your Business Strategy and the Environment Citation

How to Create a Citation for "Business Strategy and the Environment"

Creating a proper APA citation is essential for academic writing. This guide will help you craft a citation for the article from the journal "Business Strategy and the Environment." Follow the steps outlined below for a successful citation.

What You Need

  • Access to the article you wish to cite
  • Basic understanding of APA citation format
  • A computer or notepad for writing
  • Internet access for research

Step-by-Step Instructions

  1. Find the Article
    - Action: Search for the article you want to cite in the journal "Business Strategy and the Environment." Use a database like Google Scholar, your university's library database, or the journal's official website.
    - Verification: Ensure you locate the correct article by checking the title and author names.
    - Time Estimate: 10-15 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Use specific keywords such as the title or author's name to speed up your search.

  2. Gather Author Information
    - Action: Identify the authors of the article. Look for the first and last names of each author.
    - Verification: Confirm the order of authors as it appears in the article. The first author listed is the primary author.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Make a note of the authors in the correct format as you find them.

  3. Determine the Publication Year
    - Action: Locate the year of publication, which is usually found on the first page of the article or in the citation information provided by the journal.
    - Verification: Ensure the year corresponds with the article you are referencing.
    - Time Estimate: 2 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Jot down the year next to the authors to keep your notes organized.

  4. Record the Article Title
    - Action: Write down the full title of the article. Make sure to capitalize only the first word, the first word after a colon (if any), and any proper nouns.
    - Verification: Double-check the title for spelling and formatting.
    - Time Estimate: 3 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Copy and paste the title if possible to avoid errors.

  5. Identify the Journal Title, Volume, and Issue
    - Action: Find the full title of the journal, the volume number, and the issue number (if applicable). This information is typically in the header or footer of the article.
    - Verification: Ensure you have the correct journal name and numbers, as these are crucial for the citation.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Note down the volume and issue numbers right after the journal title to keep everything together.

  6. Find the Page Range
    - Action: Identify the page range of the article, which is usually listed at the beginning or end of the article.
    - Verification: Check that you have both the starting and ending pages.
    - Time Estimate: 2 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Write the page numbers down in a consistent format right after the volume and issue.

  7. Locate the DOI (Digital Object Identifier)
    - Action: Search for the DOI of the article. This can often be found on the first page of the article, in the citation details, or through a search in databases.
    - Verification: Make sure that the DOI is accurate, as it will link directly to the article.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Use the DOI link to verify it redirects to the correct article.

  8. Format the Citation
    - Action: Using the gathered information, format your citation according to the provided template. Follow the structure:
    Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx
    - Verification: Double-check that you followed the APA style guidelines for capitalization, punctuation, and italics.
    - Time Estimate: 10 minutes.
    - Tip for Efficiency: Use a citation generator to help format your citation, but always verify the output against APA guidelines.

Example of a Complete Citation

Here is an example of what your finished citation may look like:

Smith, J. A., & Doe, R. B. (2023). The impact of strategic management on environmental sustainability. Business Strategy and the Environment, 32(4), 123-145. https://doi.org/10.1000/xyz12345

Real Examples from Business Strategy and the Environment

This section provides authentic citation examples from Business Strategy and the Environment using recent publications from 2023-2024.

I'm unable to browse the internet or access external content, including specific articles from "Business Strategy and the Environment." However, I can guide you on how to construct citations in APA 7th edition format if you have the details of the articles. Below, I'll provide hypothetical examples based on typical scenarios you might encounter when citing articles from a journal:

Example 1: Standard Individual Author

1. Scenario Description:
This is a peer-reviewed journal article by a single author discussing the impact of digital transformation on sustainable business practices.

2. Complete Reference List Citation:
Smith, J. A. (2023). Digital transformation and sustainable business practices. Business Strategy and the Environment, 32(2), 123-145. https://doi.org/10.1002/bse.12345

3. In-text Citation (Parenthetical Format):
(Smith, 2023)

4. In-text Citation (Narrative Format):
Smith (2023) discusses the impact of digital transformation on sustainable business practices.

5. Notes:
This example illustrates a straightforward citation for a single-author article. The DOI is crucial for locating the digital version, and the volume and issue numbers are important for identifying the exact publication.

Example 2: Corporate Author

1. Scenario Description:
A report published by a corporate entity on the role of corporate social responsibility (CSR) in business strategy.

2. Complete Reference List Citation:
Environmental Business Group. (2023). The role of CSR in contemporary business strategy. Business Strategy and the Environment, 32(3), 234-256. https://doi.org/10.1002/bse.12346

3. In-text Citation (Parenthetical Format):
(Environmental Business Group, 2023)

4. In-text Citation (Narrative Format):
According to Environmental Business Group (2023), CSR plays a significant role in modern business strategy.

5. Notes:
Citing a corporate author can be crucial when the work is produced by an organization rather than an individual. Ensure the name of the organization is spelled out fully in the first citation.

Example 3: Multiple Authors

1. Scenario Description:
This is an article with multiple authors exploring the nexus between business strategy and environmental policy.

2. Complete Reference List Citation:
Johnson, M. L., & Lee, T. K. (2023). Integrating environmental policy with business strategy. Business Strategy and the Environment, 32(4), 345-367. https://doi.org/10.1002/bse.12347

3. In-text Citation (Parenthetical Format):
(Johnson & Lee, 2023)

4. In-text Citation (Narrative Format):
Johnson and Lee (2023) examine how environmental policy can be integrated with business strategy.

5. Notes:
This example demonstrates citing an article with two authors. In APA 7th edition, use an ampersand (&) between authors' names in parenthetical citations but spell out "and" in narrative citations.

Example 4: Special Formatting Cases

1. Scenario Description:
An article that includes a special section or a supplementary file on innovative business models for environmental sustainability.

2. Complete Reference List Citation:
Martinez, D. R., Green, S. J., & Patel, A. (2023). Innovative business models for environmental sustainability [Supplementary material]. Business Strategy and the Environment, 32(5), 456-478. https://doi.org/10.1002/bse.12348

3. In-text Citation (Parenthetical Format):
(Martinez, Green, & Patel, 2023)

4. In-text Citation (Narrative Format):
Martinez, Green, and Patel (2023) provide insights into innovative business models for environmental sustainability.

5. Notes:
Including a note about supplementary materials is essential if the article has additional content that significantly contributes to its overall findings or discussion.

These examples are fictional and for illustrative purposes only. For actual articles, always refer to the publication details provided in the journal to ensure accuracy in citation.

Common Issues When Citing Business Strategy and the Environment

Problem 1: Identifying Authors

Issue Description:
Students often struggle to identify the correct authors when citing articles from the journal "Business Strategy and the Environment" because the journal sometimes features papers with multiple authors, international collaborations, and occasionally editorial pieces without clear attribution.

Why It Happens:
This issue arises because the journal's articles frequently involve collaborations among several researchers, and the listing format can differ slightly based on authors' affiliations and contributions. Moreover, editorial notes or special issues may not always have distinct author identifications at first glance.

Solution:
1. Visit the journal's official website or database where the article is published.
2. Locate the article's title and click to open the full record.
3. Scroll to find the "Authors" section, typically located near the title or abstract.
4. Note down the authors exactly as listed, maintaining the order and format (e.g., Surname, Initials).

Before Example:
Incorrect: "John Doe et al."

After Example:
Correct: "Doe, J., Smith, A. B., & Lee, C."

Problem 2: Date Formatting

Issue Description:
Another common problem is using incorrect date formats, especially when the publication date is not clearly stated, or when differentiating between online publication and print versions.

Why It Happens:
The confusion arises because "Business Strategy and the Environment" may list different dates for online availability and print publication. Additionally, some articles might only list the year, while others provide a full date.

Solution:
1. Check the article's citation information on the journal's webpage.
2. Use the date of the online publication if available; otherwise, use the print publication date.
3. Format the date according to APA 7th edition guidelines: (Year, Month Day) if the full date is available.

Before Example:
Incorrect: "(2023)"

After Example:
Correct: "(2023, March 15)"

Problem 3: Handling URLs

Issue Description:
Students often struggle with determining when and how to include URLs, especially when the articles are accessed through institutional databases rather than directly from the journal's website.

Why It Happens:
This confusion is due to APA's guidelines which state that URLs should be included for online sources, but not for articles accessed via academic databases that do not provide a DOI or stable URL.

Solution:
1. If the article has a DOI, use it in place of a URL. Format it as "https://doi.org/xxxx".
2. If no DOI is available and the article is accessed from the journal's site, use the stable URL.
3. Do not include URLs for database-specific links.

Before Example:
Incorrect: "Retrieved from http://universitylibrary.database.com/article"

After Example:
Correct: "https://doi.org/10.1002/bse.1234"

Problem 4: Access Requirements

Issue Description:
Students may face issues accessing articles due to subscription requirements, leading to incomplete citation data.

Why It Happens:
"Business Strategy and the Environment" is often accessed through institutional subscriptions, which may limit access to certain users, complicating citation efforts for those without direct access.

Solution:
1. Use your institution's library portal to access the journal.
2. If full access is unavailable, use interlibrary loan services or request the article through academic networks.
3. Once accessed, ensure the citation includes all necessary components: author(s), date, title, journal name, volume, issue, and page numbers.

By addressing these common citation challenges, students can enhance the accuracy and reliability of their work when referencing "Business Strategy and the Environment," aligning their citations with APA 7th edition standards.

Frequently Asked Questions About Business Strategy and the Environment

Q: How can I find the correct citation information for articles from Business Strategy and the Environment on their website?

A: To locate citation information on the Business Strategy and the Environment website, navigate to the specific article page. Look for citation tools or sections labeled with terms like "Citation," "References," or "Export Citation." These sections typically provide APA citation formats or allow you to download citation details directly.

Q: How should I handle articles with multiple authors from Business Strategy and the Environment in APA format?

A: When citing articles with multiple authors, list up to 20 authors in the reference entry. For more than 20 authors, list the first 19, insert an ellipsis (‚Ä¶), and then add the final author's name. Ensure consistency in the order and format as provided by the journal.

Q: How do I address the publication date formats found in Business Strategy and the Environment articles?

A: Business Strategy and the Environment articles typically provide a publication year, volume, and issue number. In your APA citation, format the date as (Year, Month Day) if available, but often only the year is used. For example: (2023).

Q: What are the URL and access requirements for citing Business Strategy and the Environment articles?

A: Include the DOI (Digital Object Identifier) in the citation if available, as it provides a permanent link to the content. If a DOI is not available, use the URL of the journal's homepage instead of the URL from a database to ensure accessibility for future readers.

Q: How does citing Business Strategy and the Environment differ from other journal article sources in APA?

A: Citing Business Strategy and the Environment is similar to other journals in format, but pay attention to unique elements like DOIs and specific author listing practices. The journal might also have supplementary materials or specific section headings that can influence your reference list entry. Always verify the citation format against APA guidelines and the specific details provided by the journal.
